description:
Microsoft is reportedly testing a new feature in the taskbar called “Companions.” According to Windows Latest, it seems to be about support for AI agents, but exactly how it all works, well, it’s too early to say.

The references to Companions were first spotted in Build 26454 of Windows Server, but since then traces of the feature have also appeared in beta versions of Windows 11.

Possibly, the new feature could be one of the highlights of version 25H2 of Windows 11, an upgrade that will be rolled out to the public in the autumn.

Microsoft hasn’t said exac
title: Microsoft’s new feature hints at more AI integration in Windows 11

description:
E-commerce giant Amazon is now expanding its automotive business to include used cars, reports The Verge. Dealers can post their inventory directly on the platform, where customers can easily browse current deals.

This venture will start with Hyundai dealers, as Amazon already has a partnership with the South Korean automaker. They’re backing it up with solid customer protections like a three-day or 300-mile return window and at least a 30-day, 1,000-mile limited warranty on every car. After that, Amazon plans to add more car brands to the mix.

They’re starting in Los Angeles first, but the plan is to bring the service to more cities soon. This is just the latest way Amazon is trying to make buying car easier and it can’t get much easier than buying
title: Amazon now lets you buy used cars, but only if you’re in Los Angeles

description:
Free alternatives may exist for Microsoft Office components, but sometimes they can’t stand in for the original. And as a student, the new cost of $100 per year for a Microsoft 365 Personal account is pretty expensive—but fortunately, you may not have to pay to use the software.

Depending on where you go to school, you may qualify for a free or heavily discounted Microsoft 365 subscription. The student version gives you the same access to Office apps (including Microsoft Word, Excel, and PowerPoint), 1TB of OneDrive cloud storage, video editing software, and more.

For many students, your school email address will be enough to check your eligibility—and you ma
title: How to get Microsoft Office 365 for dirt cheap as a student

description:
Wait, is this mini PC really just $289? For a machine with specs this good, that almost seems too good to be true—but it’s indeed real, so you should jump on it pronto if you’ve been itching to upgrade your home office PC setup. Right now, the Beelink EQR5 mini PC is $100 off on Amazon with this awesome 25% discount!

This tiny PC is more powerful than it might seem, entirely capable of handling anything and everything you throw at it over the course of a typical day: work, leisure, browsing, streaming, even some light gaming. Specs-wise, you’re looking at an AMD Ryzen 7 5825U CPU, a massive 32GB of RAM, with an adequate 500GB PCIe 3.0 SSD. That’s fast enough for a speedy Windows 11 experience, but you can also later upgrade the parts yourself, up to 64GB of RAM and up to 8TB of storage.<
title: A Ryzen 7 laptop with 32GB RAM costs $850. This mini PC is just $299

description:
If you’ve been holding out for a premium Windows laptop to plummet in price, you’re in luck. The Samsung Galaxy Book4 360 is currently on sale for $749.99 at Best Buy, which is down from $1,349. That’s $600 off, which is pretty wild for the things you’re getting.

And what you’re getting is a pretty sweet setup. It’s got an Intel Core 7 Series 1 150U under the hood, 16GB of RAM, and a snappy 512GB SSD — so yeah, it can absolutely handle work, school, multitasking, and all the other everyday stuff you throw at it.

But the real star of the show? That 15.6-inch 1080p OLED touchscreen. It’s one of those screens that just makes everything look better — super vibrant, deep blacks, rich
title: Get this Samsung Galaxy laptop with a crisp OLED display for $600 off

description:
I love Razer’s Naga series of mice, particularly the Naga Pro, which allows you to swap out the side button panels for two, six, or twelve thumb buttons. But dang, these things are pricey. The Razer Naga Pro V2 was $180 when it launched, and it hasn’t gone down in the two years since. That’s a lot of scratch for a mouse, even for gamers.

I’ve been looking around for a more economical alternative for a while, and on Prime Day I found one. “Solakaka” isn’t exactly a household name, except in the sense that the cheap, disposable brands that litter Amazon and similar online storefronts are probably in a
title: I switched my $180 Razer Naga for this $40 mouse—and I love it
